{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3239162,"name":"","username":"hihi","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/h/5e9695/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-10-11T09:42:25.404Z","cooked":"

Hello everyone,

I attempted to implement PID control for a CIM motor controlled by the Victor SPX on the roboRIO. However, there is a challenge as the encoder is not a CANcoder and is connected to the roboRIO’s DIO port. I haven’t been able to locate a straightforward solution using CTRE’s built-in Closed Loop functionality.

Nonetheless, I’ve included some screenshots to provide a visual representation of our current setup. Thank you, everyone, for your assistance.

Best regards.

螢幕擷取畫面 2023-10-11 165509771×668 69.5 KB

螢幕擷取畫面 2023-10-11 165641397×759 53.4 KB

I’m rusty, but I think that you’ll have to run the PID on the RoboRio ~using the WPILIB~. If you want to do the closed loop on controller, you’ll need a Talon SRX and appropriate breakouts to plug the encoder directly in to the controller ~or a CANIfier/CANCoder~.

Have you considered using a language other than LabView?

Per the most recent usage statistics, barely anyone is still using LabView anymore and it’s increasingly hard to find reliable programming help in that language.

Java isn’t hard to pick up, I swear!

hihi:

I haven’t been able to locate a straightforward solution using CTRE’s built-in Closed Loop functionality.

CTRE’s closed loop functionality is only for Talon motor controllers, not Victors. Victors do not support this feature.

EveryLittleBit:

I’m rusty, but I think that you’ll have to run the PID on the RoboRio using the WPILIB.

The LabVIEW port of WPILib isn’t feature complete and doesn’t include a PID controller. LabVIEW has its own included PID controller, though I personally am not fond of it for FRC use. The unofficial WPILib LabVIEW Math library could be used, or a simple PD controller could be written (they’re not particularly complicated).

I’ll try hard and see.

EveryLittleBit:

WPILIB

I couldn’t find any information indicating that WPILIB supports LabVIEW when I checked. Additionally, there don’t appear to be any available resources for CANIfier or CANCoder at the moment.

hihi:

I attempted to implement PID control for a CIM motor controlled by the Victor SPX on the roboRIO. However, there is a challenge as the encoder is not a CANcoder and is connected to the roboRIO’s DIO port. I haven’t been able to locate a straightforward solution using CTRE’s built-in Closed Loop functionality.

This isn’t supported by CTRE’s library in any language.

Oblarg:

Per the most recent usage statistics, barely anyone is still using LabView anymore

I’m having trouble understanding this compared to your recommendation of Python in the thread below, given that LabVIEW has >3x the teams using it as Python.

Programming in Python: A good idea?

If you’re more familiar with Python than Java, use Python. I think too much is made of language choice in FRC; with the exception of LabView they’re all viable choices.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2023-10-21T16:48:59.459Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":2,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":70,"readers_count":69,"score":19.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":442161,"topic_slug":"exploring-pid-control-challenges-for-cim-motor-with-victor-spx-on-roborio","display_username":"Joe Ross","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/programming-in-python-a-good-idea/442806/10","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"Programming in Python: A good idea?","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":65,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/exploring-pid-control-challenges-for-cim-motor-with-victor-spx-on-roborio/442161/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3243670,"name":"Eli Barnett","username":"Oblarg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png","created_at":"2023-10-21T19:04:19.746Z","cooked":"

Python is extremely closely-related to other WPILib APIs; it is generally pretty easy to get support for Python from someone who knows Java, or vice-versa. The “small ecosystem” effects are way less crippling.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2023-10-21T19:04:19.746Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":61,"readers_count":60,"score":12.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":442161,"topic_slug":"exploring-pid-control-challenges-for-cim-motor-with-victor-spx-on-roborio","display_username":"Eli Barnett","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":65,"username":"Joe_Ross","name":"Joe Ross","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/joe_ross/{size}/37_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12381,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!"},"post_url":"/t/exploring-pid-control-challenges-for-cim-motor-with-victor-spx-on-roborio/442161/8","custom_user_title":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3250472,"name":"Jim simpson","username":"JSIMPSO","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/e9a140/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-11-07T14:55:43.326Z","cooked":"

As others have said, if your encoders are connected to the roboRIO, the PID needs to be run on the roboRIO.

I’m a little confused by the encoder open options you chose. Generally I’d suggest:

Here is the executing code — Put in a consistent loop – in periodic tasks.

image831×555 12.2 KB

The library functions are here:

GitHub

GitHub - jsimpso81/WPIlibMathLabVIEW: WPILib LabVIEW Math Library

WPILib LabVIEW Math Library. Contribute to jsimpso81/WPIlibMathLabVIEW development by creating an account on GitHub.

There are samples under the Help → Find Examples

image822×573 20.6 KB
